strings.Value: "Do we still know nothing about this curse?"
"Looks like we don't have a choice, then. We'll wait and prepare for the next attack."
"Linzi is right. You're too hard on yourself, Tristian."
"You should focus on solving the problem, Tristian, rather than blaming yourself."
"You're idling, Tristian. Your negligence is only helping the curse defeat us."
{n}Tristian's face glows with happiness.{/n} "We made it! The second cursed attack was repelled, and the grateful citizens of the barony have a special reward for you!"

"The second attack is over. It wasn't easy, but the barony endured it – thanks in great part to the strength and bravery of your subjects. After surviving this cycle of assaults, they are not easily caught off guard. It's a relief, but I don't think it's something we should necessarily be celebrating.
"The second attack was especially brutal. With great difficulty, your subjects managed to fight off the invasion of wild beasts. Many perished... I pray Sarenrae accepts their souls."
{n}Tristian looks at you thoughtfully and sighs.{/n} "Unfortunately, I must bring you bad news again. The Bald Hilltop lays silent for the moment, but another attack is certain to come soon.

Well, nothing that can help us contain it. Once every few months it drives nearby animals, monsters, and other beasts insane, sending them into a bloodthirsty rampage. I... don't know what action we can take on this. The only way I can help is by roughly predicting when the next attack will begin. Forgive me, {name}."
"Don't be so hard on yourself, Tristian! Even knowing when to get ready is an important thing to know! I don't know how we'd handle these attacks if they happened without warning."
{n}Tristian lowers his head.{/n} "Thank you. Your support means much to me."
"I will do everything in my power to free these lands from the curse. – I promise!"
{n}Tristian winces and takes a step back.{/n} "I... forgive me. Please forgive me."
"I don't have anything useful to add. The locals are either oblivious to the curse's origins, or they're too scared to talk. I'd be better off reading ancient books on curses..."
